awd_titl_txt: Theories of Urban Traffic Dynamics and Adaptive Control for the Age of Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will explore how big-data technologies can be applied to traffic signal control.  The project will leverage recent advances in graph theory and data science to identify distinct congestion patterns and develop unique treatments that would adaptively treat traffic congestion on urban streets. Extensive preliminary work has been conducted under idealized conditions and this research will make the leap from idealized conditions to complex, real-world settings, for significant impact in reducing congestion and aiding economic growth for the nation. Algorithms designed for this project will be open-source, with the potential to be implemented on ordinary traffic and communication infrastructures.  The development of a platform to simulate the developed algorithms in realistic settings will be a valuable teaching and outreach tool.  

The project's transformative quality lies in its plans to: (i) detect and distinguish the various geometric patterns that traffic congestion can exhibit on city streets; and (ii) target treatments to suit those distinct patterns.  The detection of geometric patterns will be pursued using big-data monitoring technologies, and by representing street networks as graphs.  Treatments envisioned for those distinct geometric patterns entail the re-timing of traffic signals, both to adaptively meter cordoned neighborhoods and to synchronize green phases to coincide with the dissipation of queues immediately downstream.  These will be integrated with another treatment that expedites bus movements past traffic signals on as-needed bases.  Specific enhancements are envisioned for existing models of neighborhood traffic, and for model-free, Reinforcement Learning approaches.  The enhanced methods will be used to predict how the treatments perform in complex, real-world settings.  The project will also explore how model and model-free predictions might be continually refined using inputs measured and processed with big-data technologies.  Further exploration will then go toward coupling the refined predictions with optimization techniques, so that treatments can adapt over the day to suit a city's evolving congestion patterns.  Once generalized in the above ways, the treatments will be tested and refined using simulation.  The aforementioned algorithms will then be designed, and the refined treatments will be coded into the simulation platform for teaching and outreach purposes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have developed simple but effective means of retiming traffic signals to combat car congestion and improve travel via public transit. We have done so by integrating the following four thrusts.

Thrusts 1 and 2: Control of car traffic from the demand- and supply-sides to decongest city streets;

Thrust 3: Queue detection, to identify when streets are ripe for intervention strategies; and

Thrust 4: Public transit, to prioritize bus movements without degrading car travel.

Outcomes are discussed below.

Signal coordination on street grids; see Sadek, et al (2022). By combining Thrusts 2 and 3, we have developed new means for synchronizing traffic signals on 4-directional street networks laid-out as rectangular grids. By resorting to an unconventional idea of using a common timing plan for all traffic signals on the grid, we show it possible to furnish exceptionally good progression for all traffic movements headed toward downtown neighborhoods in the morning rush, and away from those neighborhoods in the evening. When traffic conditions are undersaturated such that the grid is not plagued by residual queues, most commuters enjoy near-perfect synchronization and are forced to stop at no more than one red signal over their trips. As the rush wears on and conditions become oversaturated with residual queues, the strategy switches to a synchronization mode suitable for congestion: a backward progression scheme in which green times are initiated at each signal only when queues immediately downstream move forward. Work in queue detection (Thrust 3) enables an adaptive strategy that toggles between the two synchronization modes in select zones within a grid. The strategy can readily be refined to serve networks not laid out as rectangular grids. Simulations show that the adaptive strategy greatly outperforms other strategies thought to be gold standards in signal coordination. Ongoing work is now directed at field testing the strategy in real settings and at further evaluation of backward progression.

Synergistic mitigation measures; see Itani, et al (2021). By combing Thrusts 1 and 2, we show that joint deployments of a simple supply-side measure to improve street network capacity (the prohibition of vehicular left-turn maneuvers at intersections in designated zones) and a demand-side measure (congestion pricing based on travel distances) can produce synergistic outcomes that reduce travel costs more than would of the sum of deploying each measure separately.  

Bus priority in oversaturated traffic (Broniki, et al, in preparation). Work combining Thrusts 2 and 4 has found that even the most sophisticated means of altering traffic signals to prioritize bus movements are counterproductive when streets become oversaturated with residual queues. Any prioritization of buses in these cases substantially degrades car flows. This, in turn, delays buses that share lanes with cars by amounts that can substantially exceed delay savings that buses enjoy from signal prioritization. In response to this finding, we show how best to deploy bus bypass lanes in conjunction with backward signal progression, to reduce delays for both buses and cars.

Cordon metering (Doig, et al, in progress). We combined thrusts 1 and 3 to develop advancements on the use of traffic signals to meter (restrict) vehicle inflows into cordoned downtown neighborhoods during the morning rush. Protecting these destination-rich neighborhoods from congestion can reduce delay city-wide. Our studies of queues (Thrust 3) confirms that congestion sprouts in areas with excessive vehicular conflicts, and remains centered there as it expands and contracts. We show that the success of cordon metering lies in cordon placement; and that this placement should be one that maximizes the number of vehicles that are intercepted (i.e., restricted) by the metered cordon. Additional work in this vein has used Reinforcement Learning (i) to vary cordon metering rates both in time and along a cordon's circumference (Ni and Cassidy, 2019); and (ii) to expand the work from city- to regional scales (Monhanty, et al, 2020). Still more work in this realm has developed simple analytical models to realistically estimate the traffic impacts at a cordon's metered periphery (Ni and Cassidy, 2020).

Products

Kong, S., Doig Godier, J., and Cassidy, M.J. (in preparation) Backward signal coordination on urban streets.

Broniki, N., Doig Godier, J., and Cassidy, M.J. (in preparation) Prioritizing Buses on Over-Saturated Arterials via Bypass Segments.

Sadek, B., Doig Godier, J., Cassidy, M.J., and Daganzo, C.F. (2022) Traffic signal plans to decongest street networks. Transportation Research Part B, 162.

Itani, I., Cassidy, M.J., and Daganzo, C.F. (2021) Synergies of combining demand- and supply-side measures to manage congested streets. Transportation Research Part A, 151.

Mohanty, S., Pozdnukhov, A. and Cassidy, M.J. (2020) Region-wide congestion prediction and control using Deep Learning. Transportation Research Part C, 116.

Ni, W. and Cassidy, M.J. (2020) City-wide traffic control: modeling impacts of cordon queues. Transportation Research Part C, 113.

Ni., W. and Cassidy, M.J. (2019) Cordon control with spatially-varying metering rates: a Reinforced Learning approach. Transportation Research Part C, 98.
